quick-and-dirty code, `unwrap` is a good choice, which is why this lint is
`Allow` by default.

`result.unwrap()` will let the thread panic on `Err` values.
Normally, you want to implement more sophisticated error handling,
and propagate errors upwards with `?` operator.

Even if you want to panic on errors, not all `Error`s implement good
messages on display. Therefore, it may be beneficial to look at the places
where they may get displayed. Activate this lint to do just that.

docs.What it does: Checks for fully capitalized names and optionally names containing a capitalized acronym.
docs.Why is this bad:
In CamelCase, acronyms count as one word.
See [naming conventions](https://rust-lang.github.io/api-guidelines/naming.html#casing-conforms-to-rfc-430-c-case)
for more.

By default, the lint only triggers on fully-capitalized names.
You can use the `upper-case-acronyms-aggressive: true` config option to enable linting
on all camel case names
docs.Known problems:
When two acronyms are contiguous, the lint can't tell where
the first acronym ends and the second starts, so it suggests to lowercase all of
the letters in the second acronym.
docs.Example:
```rust
struct HTTPResponse;
```
Use instead:
```rust
struct HttpResponse;
```
docs.Configuration:
This lint has the following configuration variables:

* `upper-case-acronyms-aggressive: bool`: Enables verbose mode. Triggers if there is more than one uppercase char next to each other (defaults to `false`).

docs.What it does:
Checks for use of `Debug` formatting. The purpose of this
lint is to catch debugging remnants.
docs.Why is this bad:
The purpose of the `Debug` trait is to facilitate
debugging Rust code. It should not be used in user-facing output.

docs.What it does:
Checks for unnecessary repetition of structure name when a
replacement with `Self` is applicable.
docs.Why is this bad:
Unnecessary repetition. Mixed use of `Self` and struct
name
feels inconsistent.
docs.Known problems:
- Unaddressed false negative in fn bodies of trait implementations
- False positive with assotiated types in traits (#4140)
docs.Configuration:
This lint has the following configuration variables:

* `msrv: Option<String>`: The minimum rust version that the project supports (defaults to `None`).

docs.What it does:
Checks for the use of bindings with a single leading
underscore.
docs.Why is this bad:
A single leading underscore is usually used to indicate
that a binding will not be used. Using such a binding breaks this
expectation.
docs.Known problems:
The lint does not work properly with desugaring and
macro, it has been allowed in the mean time.

docs.What it does:
Checks for usage of `.as_ref()` or `.as_mut()` where the
types before and after the call are the same.
docs.Why is this bad: The call is unnecessary.

docs.What it does:
Checks for `extern crate` and `use` items annotated with
lint attributes.

This lint permits `#[allow(unused_imports)]`, `#[allow(deprecated)]`,
`#[allow(unreachable_pub)]`, `#[allow(clippy::wildcard_imports)]` and
`#[allow(clippy::enum_glob_use)]` on `use` items and `#[allow(unused_imports)]` on
`extern crate` items with a `#[macro_use]` attribute.
docs.Why is this bad:
Lint attributes have no effect on crate imports. Most
likely a `!` was forgotten.

docs.What it does:
Checks for `Into`, `TryInto`, `From`, `TryFrom`, or `IntoIter` calls
which uselessly convert to the same type.
docs.Why is this bad: Redundant code.

docs.What it does:
Checks for the use of `format!("string literal with no
argument")` and `format!("{}", foo)` where `foo` is a string.
docs.Why is this bad:
There is no point of doing that. `format!("foo")` can
be replaced by `"foo".to_owned()` if you really need a `String`. The even
worse `&format!("foo")` is often encountered in the wild. `format!("{}",
foo)` can be replaced by `foo.clone()` if `foo: String` or `foo.to_owned()`
if `foo: &str`.

docs.What it does:
Checks for variable declarations immediately followed by a
conditional affectation.
docs.Why is this bad: This is not idiomatic Rust.

docs.What it does:
Checks for transmutes to the original type of the object
and transmutes that could be a cast.
docs.Why is this bad:
Readability. The code tricks people into thinking that
something complex is going on.
docs.Example:
```rust
core::intrinsics::transmute(t); // where the result type is the same as `t`'s
```

docs.What it does:
Checks for usage of `&vec![..]` when using `&[..]` would
be possible.
docs.Why is this bad: This is less efficient.
docs.Configuration:
This lint has the following configuration variables:

* `too-large-for-stack: u64`: The maximum size of objects (in bytes) that will be linted. Larger objects are ok on the heap (defaults to `200`).

docs.What it does:
Checks for use of `Vec<Box<T>>` where T: Sized anywhere in the code.
Check the [Box documentation](https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/boxed/index.html) for more information.
docs.Why is this bad:
`Vec` already keeps its contents in a separate area on
the heap. So if you `Box` its contents, you just add another level of indirection.
docs.Known problems:
Vec<Box<T: Sized>> makes sense if T is a large type (see [#3530](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust-clippy/issues/3530),
1st comment).
docs.Configuration:
This lint has the following configuration variables:

* `vec-box-size-threshold: u64`: The size of the boxed type in bytes, where boxing in a `Vec` is allowed (defaults to `4096`).

docs.What it does: Checks for calls to `push` immediately after creating a new `Vec`.
docs.Why is this bad:
The `vec![]` macro is both more performant and easier to read than
multiple `push` calls.

docs.What it does: Finds occurrences of `Vec::resize(0, an_int)`
docs.Why is this bad: This is probably an argument inversion mistake.

docs.What it does:
Checks for bit masks that can be replaced by a call
to `trailing_zeros`
docs.Why is this bad:
`x.trailing_zeros() > 4` is much clearer than `x & 15
== 0`
docs.Known problems: llvm generates better code for `x & 15 == 0` on x86
docs.Configuration:
This lint has the following configuration variables:

* `verbose-bit-mask-threshold: u64`: The maximum allowed size of a bit mask before suggesting to use 'trailing_zeros' (defaults to `1`).

docs.What it does: Checks for use of File::read_to_end and File::read_to_string.
docs.Why is this bad:
`fs::{read, read_to_string}` provide the same functionality when `buf` is empty with fewer imports and no intermediate values.
See also: [fs::read docs](https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/fs/fn.read.html), [fs::read_to_string docs](https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/fs/fn.read_to_string.html)

docs.What it does: Checks for comparisons with an address of a trait vtable.
docs.Why is this bad:
Comparing trait objects pointers compares an vtable addresses which
are not guaranteed to be unique and could vary between different code generation units.
Furthermore vtables for different types could have the same address after being merged
together.
docs.Example:
```rust
let a: Rc<dyn Trait> = ...
let b: Rc<dyn Trait> = ...
if Rc::ptr_eq(&a, &b) {
    ...
}
```

docs.What it does:
Checks whether variables used within while loop condition
can be (and are) mutated in the body.
docs.Why is this bad:
If the condition is unchanged, entering the body of the loop
will lead to an infinite loop.
docs.Known problems:
If the `while`-loop is in a closure, the check for mutation of the
condition variables in the body can cause false negatives. For example when only `Upvar` `a` is
in the condition and only `Upvar` `b` gets mutated in the body, the lint will not trigger.

docs.What it does:
Detects `loop + match` combinations that are easier
written as a `while let` loop.
docs.Why is this bad:
The `while let` loop is usually shorter and more
readable.
docs.Known problems: Sometimes the wrong binding is displayed ([#383](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust-clippy/issues/383)).

docs.What it does: Checks for `while let` expressions on iterators.
docs.Why is this bad:
Readability. A simple `for` loop is shorter and conveys
the intent better.

docs.What it does: Checks for wildcard dependencies in the `Cargo.toml`.
docs.Why is this bad:
[As the edition guide says](https://rust-lang-nursery.github.io/edition-guide/rust-2018/cargo-and-crates-io/crates-io-disallows-wildcard-dependencies.html),
it is highly unlikely that you work with any possible version of your dependency,
and wildcard dependencies would cause unnecessary breakage in the ecosystem.
docs.Example:
```toml
[dependencies]
regex = "*"
```

docs.What it does: Checks for wildcard enum matches using `_`.
docs.Why is this bad: New enum variants added by library updates can be missed.
docs.Known problems:
Suggested replacements may be incorrect if guards exhaustively cover some
variants, and also may not use correct path to enum if it's not present in the current scope.

docs.What it does: Checks for wildcard imports `use _::*`.
docs.Why is this bad:
wildcard imports can pollute the namespace. This is especially bad if
you try to import something through a wildcard, that already has been imported by name from
a different source:

```rust
use crate1::foo; // Imports a function named foo
use crate2::*; // Has a function named foo

foo(); // Calls crate1::foo
```

This can lead to confusing error messages at best and to unexpected behavior at worst.
docs.Exceptions:
Wildcard imports are allowed from modules named `prelude`. Many crates (including the standard library)
provide modules named "prelude" specifically designed for wildcard import.

`use super::*` is allowed in test modules. This is defined as any module with "test" in the name.

These exceptions can be disabled using the `warn-on-all-wildcard-imports` configuration flag.
docs.Known problems:
If macros are imported through the wildcard, this macro is not included
by the suggestion and has to be added by hand.

Applying the suggestion when explicit imports of the things imported with a glob import
exist, may result in `unused_imports` warnings.
docs.Configuration:
This lint has the following configuration variables:

* `warn-on-all-wildcard-imports: bool`: Whether to allow certain wildcard imports (prelude, super in tests). (defaults to `false`).

docs.What it does: Checks for wildcard pattern used with others patterns in same match arm.
docs.Why is this bad:
Wildcard pattern already covers any other pattern as it will match anyway.
It makes the code less readable, especially to spot wildcard pattern use in match arm.

docs.What it does: This lint warns about the use of literals as `write!`/`writeln!` args.
docs.Why is this bad:
Using literals as `writeln!` args is inefficient
(c.f., https://github.com/matthiaskrgr/rust-str-bench) and unnecessary
(i.e., just put the literal in the format string)
docs.Known problems:
Will also warn with macro calls as arguments that expand to literals
-- e.g., `writeln!(buf, "{}", env!("FOO"))`.

docs.What it does:
This lint warns when you use `write!()` with a format
string that
ends in a newline.
docs.Why is this bad:
You should use `writeln!()` instead, which appends the
newline.

docs.What it does:
This lint warns when you use `writeln!(buf, "")` to
print a newline.
docs.Why is this bad: You should use `writeln!(buf)`, which is simpler.

docs.What it does:
This is the same as
[`wrong_self_convention`](#wrong_self_convention), but for public items.
docs.Why is this bad: See [`wrong_self_convention`](#wrong_self_convention).
docs.Known problems:
Actually *renaming* the function may break clients if
the function is part of the public interface. In that case, be mindful of
the stability guarantees you've given your users.

docs.What it does:
Checks for methods with certain name prefixes and which
doesn't match how self is taken. The actual rules are:

|Prefix |Postfix     |`self` taken           | `self` type  |
|-------|------------|-----------------------|--------------|
|`as_`  | none       |`&self` or `&mut self` | any          |
|`from_`| none       | none                  | any          |
|`into_`| none       |`self`                 | any          |
|`is_`  | none       |`&self` or none        | any          |
|`to_`  | `_mut`     |`&mut self`            | any          |
|`to_`  | not `_mut` |`self`                 | `Copy`       |
|`to_`  | not `_mut` |`&self`                | not `Copy`   |

Note: Clippy doesn't trigger methods with `to_` prefix in:
- Traits definition.
Clippy can not tell if a type that implements a trait is `Copy` or not.
- Traits implementation, when `&self` is taken.
The method signature is controlled by the trait and often `&self` is required for all types that implement the trait
(see e.g. the `std::string::ToString` trait).

Please find more info here:
https://rust-lang.github.io/api-guidelines/naming.html#ad-hoc-conversions-follow-as_-to_-into_-conventions-c-conv
docs.Why is this bad:
Consistency breeds readability. If you follow the
conventions, your users won't be surprised that they, e.g., need to supply a
mutable reference to a `as_..` function.

docs.What it does:
Checks for transmutes that can't ever be correct on any
architecture.
docs.Why is this bad: It's basically guaranteed to be undefined behaviour.
docs.Known problems:
When accessing C, users might want to store pointer
sized objects in `extradata` arguments to save an allocation.

docs.What it does: Checks for `0.0 / 0.0`.
docs.Why is this bad: It's less readable than `f32::NAN` or `f64::NAN`.

docs.What it does: Warns if an integral constant literal starts with `0`.
docs.Why is this bad:
In some languages (including the infamous C language
and most of its
family), this marks an octal constant. In Rust however, this is a decimal
constant. This could
be confusing for both the writer and a reader of the constant.

docs.What it does: Catch casts from `0` to some pointer type
docs.Why is this bad:
This generally means `null` and is better expressed as
{`std`, `core`}`::ptr::`{`null`, `null_mut`}.

docs.What it does: Checks for maps with zero-sized value types anywhere in the code.
docs.Why is this bad:
Since there is only a single value for a zero-sized type, a map
containing zero sized values is effectively a set. Using a set in that case improves
readability and communicates intent more clearly.
docs.Known problems:
* A zero-sized type cannot be recovered later if it contains private fields.
* This lints the signature of public items

docs.What it does:
Checks for `offset(_)`, `wrapping_`{`add`, `sub`}, etc. on raw pointers to
zero-sized types
docs.Why is this bad: This is a no-op, and likely unintended
